newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexican stocks close down on rates, politics fear.
newsitem.headline: Mexican stocks close down on rates, politics fear.

text.p: Mexican stocks failed to haul themselves out of the doldrums at the close of trade Tuesday amid expectations of a rise in interest rates and some political unease.
The bourse's leading index was off 42.59 points, or 1.29 percent, to stand at 3,266.99 at the close.

"Expectations that primary rate hikes of 100-150 basis points on the benchmark (28-day) Cetes (Treasury bill) rate affected the market from midday on," said Hector Chavez, an equity analyst at the Obsa brokerage house.
"I think the market's support at 3,250 points stood up very well," he added.
The market's leading indicator closed slightly above a mid-session low of 3,259.84 points.
"Early trading was definitely affected by the fall in the Dow Jones and increased 30-year Treasury bond rates following the U.S. air attack on Iraq," a floor trader said.

"Nonetheless, the (Zapatista) guerrilla's withdrawal from talks with the government was a pretext for taking more profits," he added, referring to news the Chiapas rebels had suspended talks with the government.
The trader said the market broke through its 26-day moving average on the downside during the session, so that the bourse's support level is now at 3,100 points.
A total of 78.72 million shares changed hands in 3,101 trades held during the session. The market scoreboard showed 59 losers and 15 winners, with the remaining 17 stocks unchanged.
Telmex L shares gained a scant two centavos (half a cent) to 12.40 pesos ($1.64) on arbitrage due to peso losses, while its ADRs traded in New York closed 1/8 down at $32-3/4.
